[[Zagreb]]
[[Tovarnik]]
[[Bogdanovci]]
[[Lovas, Croatia|Lovas]]
[[Nuštar]] | coordinates = | causes = Start of application of bilingualism officially introduced in 2009 in town of [[Vukovar]] | status = | goals = opposition to usage of minority languages and seeking modification of Constitutional Law on National Minorities rights | result = | methods = | notes= [http://stozer-vukovar.com/ HQs for defense of Croatian Vukovar]}} [[File:20130609 Zagreb 041.jpg|thumbnail|Anti-Cyrillic Graffiti depicting the U symbol of the [[Ustashe]]]] '''Anti-[[Cyrillic]] protests in Croatia''' were a series of protests in late 2013 against the application of bilingualism in [[Vukovar]], whereby [[Serbian language|Serbian]] and the [[Serbian Cyrillic alphabet]] were assigned co-official status due to the local minority population. The implementation of this decision became mandatory after the [[2011 Croatian census]], according to which Serbs in Vukovar comprise more than one-third (34.8%) of Vukovar's total population.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-20899868|title=Croatia plans Cyrillic signs for Serbs in Vukovar|date=3 January 2013|accessdate=25 October 2013|work=BBC News}} Signs in the [[Serbian Cyrillic alphabet]] had been put up as the [[Constitutional Act on the Rights of National Minorities in the Republic of Croatia|Constitutional Act on the Rights of National Minorities]] mandates bilingual signs in any area where more than one-third of the population belongs to an ethnic minority.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-23934098|title=Croatians tear down Serbian signs|date=2 September 2013|accessdate=25 October 2013|work=BBC News}}{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/europe/2013/04/201347172816369285.html|title=Croatians protest against Cyrillic signs|author=[[Al Jazeera English]]|date=7 April 2013|accessdate=25 October 2013}} This decision became subject of intense agitation by, among others, Croatian war veterans and many ordinary citizens who believe that due to events, particularly the [[Battle of Vukovar]], the city should have been excluded from the application of the law on minority rights, although protests and vandalism have occurred in other towns and cities (i.e. Split, Dubrovnik, etc). The [[Serbs of Croatia]] are a minority group that have the narrowest usage of right to bilingualism among all national minorities in Croatia.{{cite web|url=http://www.slobodnaevropa.org/content/pravo-na-dvojezicnost-od-primjene-do-negiranja/24936733.html|title=Pravo na dvojezičnost: Od primjene do negiranja|author=[[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]]|date=23 March 2013|accessdate=25 October 2013}} The Group called ''HQs for defense of Croatian Vukovar'' initiated protest rallies on 2 September, as soon as the placement of the signs written in both the Latin and the Cyrillic scripts began in Vukovar.{{cite web|url=http://daily.tportal.hr/286262/Over-1-000-rally-in-Vukovar-against-Cyrillic-signs.html |title=Over 1,000 rally in Vukovar against Cyrillic signs |author=T-portal |date=14 September 2013 |accessdate=25 October 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029185515/http://daily.tportal.hr/286262/Over-1-000-rally-in-Vukovar-against-Cyrillic-signs.html |archivedate=29 October 2013 }} With protests in [[Vukovar]], in April 2013 there were also organized protests in [[Zagreb]]'s main square with around 20,000 participants.{{cite news|url = https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/09/02/us-croatia-protest-idUSBRE9810AQ20130902|title=Croats tear down signs put up for Serb minority|work=[[Reuters]]|date=2 September 2013|accessdate=2013-10-25}} Parallel protests were held in [[Tovarnik]],{{cite web|url=http://daily.tportal.hr/285368/Anti-Cyrillic-protests-enter-9th-day.html |title=Anti-Cyrillic protests enter 9th day |author=[[T-portal]] |date=10 September 2013 |accessdate=25 October 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029191337/http://daily.tportal.hr/285368/Anti-Cyrillic-protests-enter-9th-day.html |archivedate=29 October 2013 }} [[Bogdanovci]],{{cite web|url=http://vinkovacka.tv/sve-vijesti/novosti/1989-potpora-i-iz-lovasa|title=Potpora i iz Lovasa|work=[[Vinkovačka televizija]]|date=12 September 2013|accessdate=25 October 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029193129/http://vinkovacka.tv/sve-vijesti/novosti/1989-potpora-i-iz-lovasa#|archive-date=29 October 2013|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} [[Lovas, Croatia|Lovas]], and [[Nuštar]].{{cite web|url=http://vinkovacka.tv/sve-vijesti/novosti/1979-potpora-iz-nutra|title=Potpora iz Nuštra|work=[[Vinkovačka televizija]]|date=5 September 2013|accessdate=25 October 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029195424/http://vinkovacka.tv/sve-vijesti/novosti/1979-potpora-iz-nutra#|archive-date=29 October 2013|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} A number of signs in the [[Serbian Cyrillic alphabet]] were torn down, others were smashed with hammers, and protesters clashed with the police, leaving four police officers slightly injured.{{cite web|url=http://www.globalpost.com/dispatch/news/afp/130906/anti-serbian-language-protests-highlight-croatia-tensions|title=Anti-Serbian language protests highlight Croatia tensions|work=[[GlobalPost]]|date=6 September 2013|accessdate=25 October 2013}} Some of supporters not directly connected to the protesters organized actions of writing [[pro-fascist]] [[Ustaše]] graffiti on the Orthodox [[Church of the Holy Annunciation, Dubrovnik|Church of the Holy Annunciation]] in [[Dubrovnik]] and in [[Zadar]].{{cite web|url=http://www.vecernji.hr/vijesti/ustaska-obiljezja-osvanula-pravoslavnoj-crkvi-dubrovniku-clanak-607612|title=Ustaška obilježja osvanula na pravoslavnoj crkvi u Dubrovniku|work=[[Večernji list]]|date=3 September 2013|accessdate=25 October 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://www.jutarnji.hr/grafiti-na-ulazu-u-dubrovnik-i-na-prevoslavnoj-crkvi--srbe-na-vrbe---i--smrt-izdajnicima---/1123864|title=FOTO: POD OKRILJEM NOĆI ISPISALI SRAMOTNE GRAFITE U DUBROVNIKU 'Srbe na vrbe!' i 'Stop ćirilici u Vukovaru!'|work=[[Jutarnji list]]|date=3 September 2013|accessdate=25 October 2013}} On 12 August 2014 [[Constitutional Court of Croatia]] decided that referendum proposal on the restriction of the use of minority languages in such a way to increase the required proportion of total population to 50%, is unconstitutional.{{cite web|url=http://narodne-novine.nn.hr/clanci/sluzbeni/2014_08_104_2021.html|title=Odluka Ustavnog suda o referendumskom pitanju|work=[[Constitutional Court of Croatia]]|date=12 August 2014|accessdate=25 August 2015}} City Council of Vukovar was required to regulate the use of minority language in its statute within a year after court decision. [[Government of Croatia]] was required to define legal mechanism for cases when the representative bodies of local self-government does not implement the obligations under the Law regarding minority languages. National authorities competent for implementation of laws on minority languages were instructed not to implement Law in the City of Vukovar by use of coercive measures until Government of Croatia fulfill its obligation. In April 2015 [[United Nations Human Rights Committee]] urged Croatia to ensure the right of minorities to use their language and alphabet.{{cite web|url=http://www.b92.net/eng/news/region.php?yyyy=2015&mm=04&dd=03&nav_id=93697|title=UN calls on Croatia to ensure use of Serbian Cyrillic|work=B92.net|date=3 April 2015|accessdate=11 April 2015}} Committee report stated that particularly concerns the use of Serbian Cyrillic in the town of Vukovar and municipalities concerned. Serbian Foreign Minister [[Ivica Dačić]] said that his country welcomes the UN Human Rights Committee's report.{{cite web|url=http://www.tanjug.rs/news/172551/serbia-welcomes-un-stance-on-use-of-cyrillic-in-croatia.htm |title=Serbia welcomes UN stance on use of Cyrillic in Croatia |work=[[Tanjug]] |date=3 April 2015 |accessdate=11 April 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150411211332/http://www.tanjug.rs/news/172551/serbia-welcomes-un-stance-on-use-of-cyrillic-in-croatia.htm |archivedate=11 April 2015 |df= }} On 17 August 2015, under requirement of [[Constitutional Court of Croatia]], the City Council of Vukovar decided to amend the city statute in such a way as not to provide bilingual signs in Latin and Cyrillic scripts at official town buildings, institutions, squares and streets. [[Council of Europe]] stated its regret about this decision.{{cite web|url=http://www.coe.int/en/web/portal/home/-/asset_publisher/CWAECqDHgT3y/content/council-of-europe-supports-use-of-minority-languages-in-public-signs?inheritRedirect=false&redirect=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.coe.int%2Fen%2Fweb%2Fportal%2Fhome%3Fp_p_id%3D101_INSTANCE_CWAECqDHgT3y%26p_p_lifecycle%3D0%26p_p_state%3Dnormal%26p_p_mode%3Dview%26p_p_col_id%3Dcolumn-2%26p_p_col_count%3D1|title=Council of Europe supports use of minority languages in public signs|work=[[Council of Europe]]|date=21 August 2015|accessdate=25 August 2015}} Decision was taken by MP's from [[Croatian Democratic Union]] and [[Croatian Democratic Alliance of Slavonia and Baranja]] while MP's FROM [[Social Democratic Party of Croatia]], [[Independent Democratic Serb Party]] and [[Croatian People's Party – Liberal Democrats]] left session at which the decision was taken.{{cite web|url=http://www.telegram.hr/politika-kriminal/gradsko-vijece-nakon-burne-sjednice-odlucilo-ukinuti-table-na-cirilici-u-vukovaru/|title=Vijeće na burnoj sjednici izmijenilo statut, ukinulo ćirilicu u Vukovaru|work=[[Tanjug]]|date=3 April 2015|accessdate=11 April 2015}} [[Ministry of Public Administration (Croatia)]] announced that it would overturn the decision if it is established to be contrary to the constitution.{{cite web|url=http://www.index.hr/vijesti/clanak/ministarstvo-uprave-ukinut-cemo-odluku-ako-je-izbacivanje-cirilice-iz-vukovara-protivno-ustavu/836927.aspx|title=Ministarstvo uprave ukinut će odluku ako je izbacivanje ćirilice iz Vukovara protivno Ustavu|work=[[Index.hr]]|date=18 August 2015|accessdate=25 August 2015}} The local civic society ''The city, that's us too'' suggested that the dispute could be resolved by putting on the right side of the entrance to local government buildings a sign in Croatian Latin script, and on the left side a sign in the languages and scripts of ethnic minorities living in Vukovar.[http://dalje.com/en-croatia/civil-society-group-proposes-solution-to-bilingualism-dispute-in-vukovar/523185 Recommended solution to dispute], dalje.com; accessed 2 June 2015. ==Reactions== ==={{flagicon|Croatia}}Croatia=== ====Opposition==== *[[Croatian President]] [[Ivo Josipović]] joined in the condemnation of the events in Vukovar, saying that an added effort must be invested to prevent violence and tensions. “We have the law which goes toward full respect of the national minorities. All relevant political parties in Croatia took part in passing this law,” Josipovic said.{{cite web|url=http://www.tanjug.rs/news/98308/protest-in-vukovar-against-cyrillic-script.htm |title=Protests against Cyrillic in Vukovar, graffiti in Dubrovnik |author=[[Tanjug]] |date=3 September 2013 |accessdate=25 October 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029190443/http://www.tanjug.rs/news/98308/protest-in-vukovar-against-cyrillic-script.htm |archivedate=29 October 2013 }} *[[Croatian Prime Minister]] [[Zoran Milanović]] condemned "chauvinist violence", saying it will not take down signs in Cyrillic in Vukovar as the "rule of law must prevail".{{cite web|url=http://www.thesundaily.my/news/822967|title=Anti-Serbian language protests highlight Croatia tensions|work=[[The Sun (Malaysia)]]|date=6 September 2013|accessdate=2013-10-25}}{{cite web|url=http://www.neurope.eu/article/croatia-veterans-tear-down-serbian-signs7 |title=Croatia veterans tear down Serbian signs |work=[[New Europe (newspaper)|New Europe]] |date=2 September 2013 |accessdate=25 October 2013 }}{{dead link|date=July 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} *Former Croatian President [[Stjepan Mesić]] claimed the protests in Zagreb were not ... a democratic expression of different opinions, but of intolerance... The appearance of people in military uniforms at such place ... clearly violate state law. If we consider publicly and unambiguously imposed threats that they will by using force prevent implementation of duties that every citizen and every institution is obligatory to do by Constitution, Sunday gathering at main square look like blow to the constitutional and [[Rule of law|legal order]] of our country.{{cite web|url=http://www.novilist.hr/Vijesti/Hrvatska/Mesic-Poruke-sa-skupa-protiv-cirilice-udar-su-na-ustavni-poredak|title=Mesić: Poruke sa skupa protiv ćirilice udar su na ustavni poredak|language=Croatian|work=[[Novi List]]|date=8 April 2013|accessdate=3 November 2013}} *Vukovar mayor [[Željko Sabo]], a veteran of the [[Yugoslav Wars]], who had been imprisoned in Serbia, appealed for people to stay calm and “not let Vukovar become [[Hundred Days' War|Beirut]]”. *Croatian foreign minister [[Vesna Pusić]] said that Croatians “must and can” obey Croatian laws and said that government must stand firm on the minorities legislation. *[[Dragan Crnogorac (politician)|Dragan Crnogorac]], president of [[Joint Council of Municipalities]], expressed concern and regret over events in Vukovar and rest of Croatia. He said that these events create a negative atmosphere directed towards the Serbian community and the Cyrillic alphabet. In this way, they undermines everything that has been achieved in previous years in building [[Toleration|tolerance]] and [[cohabitation]] among Serbs and Croats.{{cite web|url=http://www.zvo.hr/index.php?meni=888&idt=21|script-title=sr:Ћирилица није ратни демон него средство комуникације|work=[[Joint Council of Municipalities]]|date=9 October 2013|language=Serbian|accessdate=25 October 2013}} *Bojan Glavašević, son of Croatian reporter [[Siniša Glavašević]], killed by Serb paramilitaries after the [[Battle of Vukovar]], said that use of his father's voice at the protest in Zagreb was inappropriate and that the name of his father was being used for political marketing. He said everyone has a right to peaceful protest, but condemned hate speech on the protests.{{cite web|url=http://www.seebiz.eu/bojan-glavasevic-koristenje-snimaka-mog-oca-na-prosvjedu-nije-bilo-primjereno/ar-61257|title=Bojan Glavašević: Korištenje snimaka mog oca na prosvjedu nije bilo primjereno|work=SEEbiz/Media Servis|date=7 April 2013|language=Croatian|accessdate=2 November 2013}} *26 NGOs in Croatia sent a joint letter to [[Pope Francis]], voicing concern about the stance of Croatian Cardinal [[Josip Bozanić]] and several bishops who publicly demonstrated their opposition to bilingualism in Vukovar. The NGOs highlighted that the bishops' statements do not contribute to peace and reconciliation, but rather lead to further deepening of conflicts.{{cite web|url=http://www.b92.net/eng/news/region.php?yyyy=2013&mm=11&dd=18&nav_id=88366|title=Letter sent to pope over anti-Cyrillic sentiment in Croatia|work=B92.net|date=18 November 2013|accessdate=30 March 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.kriz-zivota.com/gradanske-inicijative-i-organizacije-poslale-pismo-papi-franji |title=Građanske inicijative i organizacije poslale pismo papi Franji |work=Križ života |language=Croatian |date=15 November 2013 |accessdate=30 March 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140223100009/http://kriz-zivota.com/gradanske-inicijative-i-organizacije-poslale-pismo-papi-franji/ |archivedate=23 February 2014 }} *Archbishop of Đakovo-Osijek [[Đuro Hranić]] [[Đuro Hranić#Reaction on 2013 Anti-Cyrillic protests|called for mutual respect and love]].http://www.ika.hr/index.php?prikaz=vijest&ID=155532 ====Support==== *The County Council of [[Vukovar-Srijem County]] gave support to protesters in their intent "to stop the violent introduction of bilingualism in Vukovar". During the vote Council members of [[Social Democratic Party of Croatia]], [[Croatian Party of Pensioners]] and [[Independent Democratic Serb Party]] left the session.{{cite web|url=http://vinkovacka.tv/sve-vijesti/novosti/2042-upanijska-skuptina-protiv-dvojezinosti|title=Županijska skupština protiv dvojezičnosti|work=Vinkovačka televizija|date=3 October 2013|accessdate=25 October 2013|archive-url=https://archive.is/20131025202016/http://vinkovacka.tv/sve-vijesti/novosti/2042-upanijska-skuptina-protiv-dvojezinosti#|archive-date=25 October 2013|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} *Representatives of Associations of Croat Returnees of [[Eastern Slavonia, Baranja and Western Syrmia (1995–98)#Croats from the region|Eastern Slavonia, Baranja and Western Syrmia]] gave its support to all the demands by the ''HQs for defense of Croatian Vukovar''.{{cite web|url=http://vinkovacka.tv/sve-vijesti/novosti/2013-potpora-stoeru|title=Potpora Stožeru|work=Vinkovačka televizija|date=20 September 2013|accessdate=25 October 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029193328/http://vinkovacka.tv/sve-vijesti/novosti/2013-potpora-stoeru#|archive-date=29 October 2013|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} ===International=== ====Former [[Yugoslavia]]==== ====={{flagicon|Serbia}}[[Serbia]]===== *The [[Serbian Progressive Party]] condemned the protests, urging Zagreb to protect Serb minority rights.{{cite web|url=http://www.balkaninsight.com/en/article/serbia-condemns-anti-cyrillic-protests-in-vukovar|title=Serbia Condemns Anti-Cyrillic Protests in Croatia|work=[[Balkan Insight]]|date=5 September 2013|accessdate=25 October 2013}} *The Coalition of Serbian Refugees from Croatia, which represents many Serbs who fled Croatia at the end of the war in 1995, said the protests were another example of violations of minority rights in Croatia. ====={{flagicon|Slovenia}} [[Slovenia]]===== * Then-European Parliament Rapporteur for Serbia [[Jelko Kacin]] said that he expected a "clear response" from Zagreb.{{cite web|url=http://www.blic.rs/Vesti/Svet/403054/Kacin-ocekuje-pravu-i-jasnu-reakciju-Zagreba|title=Kacin očekuje pravu i jasnu reakciju Zagreba|work=[[Blic]]|date=9 September 2013|accessdate=2 November 2013}} ====Other==== ====={{flagicon|European Union}} [[European Union]]===== *[[European Commission]] spokesperson [[Dennis Abbott (European Commission)|Dennis Abbott]] said that European Union has no intention of interfering in the dispute over Cyrillic signs in Vukovar. He reminded the belligerents that respect for cultural diversity and minority rights is enshrined in fundamental documents of EU, but that jurisdiction in these matters are under every member state.{{cite web|url=http://www.rts.rs/page/stories/sr/story/11/Region/1392046/EU+se+ne%C4%87e+me%C5%A1ati+u+spor+oko+%C4%87irilice.html|title=EU se neće mešati u spor oko ćirilice|work=[[Radio Television of Serbia]]|date=9 September 2013|accessdate=31 October 2013}} ====={{flagicon|Council of Europe}} [[Council of Europe]]===== *On 21 August 2015 [[Council of Europe]], prompt by Vukovar City Council decision to amend the city statute in such a way as not to provide bilingual signs in Latin and Cyrillic scripts at official town buildings, institutions, squares and streets, stated that this institution ''strongly regrets the removal of signs in minority languages through vandalism or pursuant to formal decisions aiming at limiting the presence of minority languages in the public and urges all relevant public authorities in all States Parties to fully implement the provisions of the European Charter for Regional or Minority Languages''. ==Chronology== ===2015=== *'''21 August''' [[Council of Europe]] stated its regret about City Council decision. *'''17 August''' City Council of Vukovar decided to amend the city statute in such a way as not to provide bilingual signs in Latin and Cyrillic scripts. ===2014=== *'''23 September''': Members of the Headquarters for Defense of Croat Vukovar removed all bilingual signs in the city; 5 of them were later placed under arrest.[inserbia.info/today/2014/09/croatia-all-bilingual-signs-removed-and-smashed-in-vukovar/ InSerbia News]; accessed 27 May 2015. *'''12 August''': [[Constitutional Court of Croatia]] decision on non-constitutionality of ''HQs for defense of Croatian Vukovar'' referendum proposal *'''16 March''': A [[Flag of Serbs of Croatia|Serbs of Croatia flag]] was stolen from municipal government building in [[Borovo, Croatia|Borovo]].{{cite journal|script-title=sr:Табле разбија ко стигне|journal=Izvor, magazine of [[Joint Council of Municipalities]]|number=89|date=March 2014|location=[[Vukovar]]|url=http://issuu.com/tvprodukcijazvo/docs/89|accessdate=30 March 2014|language=Serbian}} *'''14 March''': Bilingual sign of State Administration Office in Vukovar was broken. *'''6 March''': Bilingual sign of Croatian Employment Service in Vukovar was broken. *'''24 January''': [[Member of the European Parliament]] of [[European Conservatives and Reformists]] group [[Ruža Tomašić]] stated that ''Serbs in Vukovar should not get anything since they are the ones who destroyed the town (sic) in collaboration with [[Yugoslav People's Army]].''{{cite web|url=http://www.tportal.hr/vijesti/svijet/311611/Srpska-manjina-je-s-jugovojskom-sravnila-Vukovar-sa-zemljom.html|title='Srpska manjina je s jugovojskom sravnila Vukovar sa zemljom'|work=[[T-portal]]|date=24 January 2014|accessdate=31 March 2014}} *'''7 January 7''': Unknown perpetrators destroyed a bilingual sign on [[Serb National Council]] building in [[Pula]].{{cite web|url=http://www.tportal.hr/vijesti/crnakronika/308282/Isarali-cirilicni-natpis-u-Puli.html|title=Išarali ćirilični natpis u Puli|work=[[T-portal]]|date=7 January 2014|accessdate=30 July 2014}} *'''5 January''': Six bilingual signs destroyed in Vukovar.{{cite web|url=http://www.tportal.hr/vijesti/crnakronika/308104/Policija-traga-za-razbijacima-cirilicnih-ploca.html|title=Policija traga za razbijačima ćiriličnih ploča|work=[[T-portal]]|date=8 January 2014|accessdate=30 March 2014}} *'''3 January''': [[Patriarch Irinej of Serbia]] in Christmas letter stated that prosecution of Cyrillic is the same as persecuting Serbs.{{cite web|url=http://www.jutarnji.hr/patrijarh-irinej--progon-cirilice-koristi-kao-paravan-za-nastavak-progona-srba-u-hrvatskoj-/1151782|title=PATRIJARH IRINEJ: 'Progon ćirilice je paravan za novi progon Srba u Hrvatskoj'|work=Jutarnji list|date=3 January 2014|accessdate=30 March 2014}} ===2013=== *'''20 December''': Destroyed bilingual signs in Vukovar and on Elementary School in [[Mirkovci]]. *'''16 December''': ''HQs for defense of Croatian Vukovar'' submitted signatures for referendum. *'''13 December''': Bilingual signs graffitied in Vukovar. *'''7 December''': MP [[Milorad Pupovac]] received death threats. *'''2 December''': Threatening messages sent to Director of [[Jasenovac concentration camp]] memorial area. *'''21 November''': Ministry of Public Administration suspended provisions of town statutes that limits usage of minority language.{{cite web|url=http://www.slobodnadalmacija.hr/Hrvatska/tabid/66/articleType/ArticleView/articleId/228154/Default.aspx|title=Ministarstvo uprave: Vukovar neće biti izuzet od uvođenja dvojezičnosti; HDZ čeka Ustavni sud|work=[[Slobodna Dalmacija]]|date=21 November 2013|accessdate=2 April 2014}} *'''19 November''': [[Josip Šimunić#Salute after Croatia-Iceland game|neo-Nazi]] salute ("[[Za dom spremni|Za dom]]") at the Croatia-Iceland football game. *'''19 November''': [[FIFA]] delegate requested removal of banner ''Zapamtite Vukovar'' ([[English language|English]]: Remember Vukovar) from [[Stadion Maksimir]] before the Croatia-Iceland football match.{{cite web|url=http://www.vecernji.hr/nogomet/delegat-fife-naredio-skidanje-transparenta-zapamtite-vukovar-904001|title=Delegat Fife naredio skidanje transparenta 'Zapamtite Vukovar'|work=[[Večernji list]]|date=20 November 2013|accessdate=27 May 2015}} *'''19 November''': Bilingual sign removed from the [[Trpinja]] municipality building; flag of Serbs of Croatia stolen. *'''18 November''': State delegation led by Prime Minister [[Zoran Milanović]] and President [[Ivo Josipović]] blocked from participating in fall of Vukovar "memory walk" by ''HQs for defense of Croatian Vukovar''.{{Clarify|date=May 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.tportal.hr/vijesti/svijet/299414/Svjetski-mediji-o-diverziji-u-Vukovaru.html|title=Svjetski mediji o diverziji u Vukovaru|author=T-portal|date=18 November 2013|accessdate=31 March 2014}} *'''18 November''': President of [[Serb National Council]] [[Milorad Pupovac]] for the first time participated in "memory walk" which commemorates the [[Battle of Vukovar]]. The event was attended by [[Veljko Džakula]], president of [[Serb Democratic Forum]].{{cite web|url=http://www.tportal.hr/vijesti/hrvatska/299424/Na-veliku-vukovarsku-nesrecu-ovo-je-jos-jedna-nesreca.html|title='Na veliku vukovarsku nesreću, ovo je još jedna nesreća'|work=[[T-portal]]|date=18 November 2013|accessdate=31 March 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.tportal.hr/vijesti/hrvatska/299410/Tomislav-Josic-trijumfira-zbog-blokade-drzavnog-vrha.html|title=Tomislav Josić trijumfira zbog blokade državnog vrha|work=T-portal|date=18 November 2013|accessdate=31 March 2014}} *'''17 November''': Bilingual signage stolen in Osijek for the third time. *'''17 November''': ''HQs for defense of Croatian Vukovar'' began collecting signatures for referendum for limitation of rights on usage of minority languages. *'''12 November''': Two drunk member of the ''HQs for defense of Croatian Vukovar'' broke sign on Police station in Vukovar and clashed with police and one ended up in hospital. *'''12 November''': Table on [[Serb National Council]] building in Osijek painted. *'''9 November''': Two men (both 18 years old) damage a sign on the Consulate General of Serbia in [[Rijeka]]. *'''6 November''': Graffiti ("Serbian family tree") with a picture of lynched people appeared on [[Ban Jelačić Square]]. *'''5 November''': Bilingual memorial plaque for [[Macedonians (ethnic group)|Macedonian]] writer Andrej Petkovic in [[Rijeka]] is damaged. *'''5 November''': "Serbs out" graffiti written in Vukovar. *'''4 November''': Minister of Veterans Predrag Matić stated in ''[[Večernji list]]'' that the Serbs of Croatia are not loyal to Croatia. *'''4 November''': City Council adopted a new statute of Vukovar and prohibited usage of Cyrillic. *'''3 November''': Bilingual sign of the [[Serb National Council]] building in [[Varaždin]] is damaged. *'''2 November''': Bilingual sign removed from the [[Serb National Council]] building in [[Osijek]] for the second time. *'''25 October''': Removed bilingual sign from [[Serb National Council]] building in [[Osijek]]. *'''22 October''': Removed bilingual signs from Employment Service buildings in Vukovar. *'''19 October''': Removed bilingual signs from State Administration buildings in Vukovar. *'''12 October''': Removed bilingual sign from [[Vojnić]] municipality building. *'''12 October''': Removed bilingual sign from [[Biskupija]] municipality building. *'''11 October''': Three bilingual signs destroyed at the [[Udbina]] municipality building. *'''8 October''': An unknown offender removed bilingual sign from [[Prosvjeta]] building in Zagreb. *'''7 October''': A group of Croatian war veterans removed bilingual signs from three buildings in Vukovar. *'''23 September''': The president of the Coordination of Associations of Croat Returnees sprayed Cyrillic inscription on Pension insurance building in Vukovar. *'''16 September''': An unknown offender removed bilingual sign from [[Krnjak]] municipality building. *'''13 September''': Monument for Serb victims from war destroyed in [[Golubić, Šibenik-Knin County|Golubić]]. *'''5 September''': Local ''HQs for defense of Croatian Vukovar'' established in [[Slunj]]; around 100 protesters gathered in support of the removal of bilingual plaques in Vukovar. The mayor of Slunj distanced himself from them as unnecessary and serving the political ends of the organizer(s).{{cite web|url=http://www.tportal.hr/vijesti/hrvatska/284335/U-Slunju-osnovan-jos-jedan-Stozer-za-obranu-hrvatskog-Vukovara.html|title=U Slunju osnovan još jedan Stožer za obranu hrvatskog Vukovara|work=T-portal|date=5 September 2013|accessdate=31 March 2014}} *'''4 September''': An explosive device thrown at the local [[Serb National Council]] building in [[Split, Croatia|Split]]. *'''4 September''': [[Josip Leko]], Speaker of the Croatian Parliament, stated there would not be an emergency session which had been requested by [[Croatian Democratic Alliance of Slavonia and Baranja]].{{cite web|url=https://dnevnik.hr/vijesti/hrvatska/leko-dogadzaji-u-vukovaru-malo-podsjecaju-na-splitsku-rivu---301393.html|title=Leko: Događaji u Vukovaru malo podsjećaju na Splitsku rivu|work=[[Dnevnik Nove TV]]|date=4 September 2013|accessdate=31 March 2014}} *'''3 September''': The Croatian Democratic Alliance of Slavonia and Baranja requested an emergency session of [[Croatian Parliament]] over Vukovar events.{{cite web|url=https://dnevnik.hr/vijesti/hrvatska/hdssb-trazi-izvanrednu-saborsku-sjednicu---301259.html|title=HDSSB traži izvanrednu saborsku sjednicu|work=[[Dnevnik Nove TV]]|date=3 September 2013|accessdate=31 March 2014}} *'''3 September'''" Graffiti ("[[Srbe na vrbe]]") scrawled on a wall of the Orthodox [[Church of the Holy Annunciation, Dubrovnik|Church of the Holy Annunciation]] in [[Dubrovnik]]. *'''2 September''': Bilingual signs broken in Vukovar. Several police officers were injured.{{cite journal|script-title=sr:Олуја која не престаје (2)|journal=Izvor Magazine|author=[[Joint Council of Municipalities]]|number=83|date=December 2013|location=Vukovar|url=http://www.zvo.hr/izvor/9bd5da1f8af26d3.pdf|accessdate=30 March 2014|language=Serbian|title=Archived copy|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140331010648/http://www.zvo.hr/izvor/9bd5da1f8af26d3.pdf#|archive-date=31 March 2014|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} ==Historical bans on usage of Cyrillic in Vukovar== {{see also|Serbian language in Croatia}} In 1861 General Assembly of [[Syrmia County]] unanimously adopted decision on introduction of the [[Serbian Cyrillic alphabet]] as official alphabet on the territory of county.{{cite web|url=http://www.zvo.hr/izvor/e9860c3c169d9c9.pdf|title=Царе Фрањо помози!|format=PDF|work=[[Joint Council of Municipalities]]|accessdate=10 November 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131110172352/http://www.zvo.hr/izvor/e9860c3c169d9c9.pdf#|archive-date=10 November 2013|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} This decision was reversed eight years later in 1869 when the Parliament of [[Kingdom of Croatia-Slavonia]] adopted decision on exclusive usage of [[Gaj's Latin alphabet]] and repealed the county decision on usage of Cyrillic. This caused dissatisfaction among the Serbs of Vukovar who sent a [[letter of protest]] to Emperor [[Franz Joseph I of Austria]] since the [[Kingdom of Croatia-Slavonia]] was part of [[Austro-Hungarian Empire]]. Citizens of Vukovar asked the emperor to protect his subjects from the parliament's decision, pointing out that the decision was unreasonable, especially since even the [[Diet of Hungary]] of the [[Lands of the Crown of Saint Stephen]] accepted their letters in Cyrillic. During [[World War II]], the [[Serbian Cyrillic alphabet]] was banned throughout the [[Independent State of Croatia]].{{cite web|url=http://www.b92.net/info/vesti/index.php?yyyy=2013&mm=10&dd=25&nav_id=769690|title=Ante Pavelić prvi zabranio ćirilicu|author=[[B92]]|accessdate=10 November 2013}} State sanctioned [[Bookocide in Croatia|Bookocide]] was carried out by the [[Government of the Republic of Croatia]] between 1990 and 2010. Books that were written in [[Serbian Cyrillic]] were burned with an estimated 2,8 million books destroyed in this period.{{cite web |url=https://www.slobodnaevropa.org/a/knjigocid-u-hrvatskoj-hronika-sramnog-vremena/25129713.html |title=Knjigocid u Hrvatskoj: Hronika sramnog vremena |last=Jakšić |first=Božidar |date= 8 October 2013 |website=www.slobodnaevropa.org |publisher=Radio Free Europe |access-date= 9 May 2018 |quote=Dragoceno je svjedočanstvo, koje navodi autor, izjava ministra finansija Republike Hrvatske Borislava Škegra iz 1997. godine da će se sredstvima državnog proračuna finansirati biblioteke da iz knjižnih fondova izbace knjige na srpskom i sličnim jezicima“, objašnjava Jakšić.}} On 5 November 2013, the [[Croatian Democratic Union]] and [[Croatian Party of Rights dr. Ante Starčević]] adopted amendments to the city's statutes, declaring Vukovar to be a "place of special reverence" of the Serbian destruction of the town during the [[Battle of Vukovar]] and prohibited usage of [[Serbian Cyrillic alphabet]].{{cite web|url=http://www.balkaninsight.com/en/article/zabranjena-%C4%87irilica-u-vukovaru|title=Zabranjena ćirilica u Vukovaru|work=[[Balkan Insight]]|accessdate=10 November 2013}} [[Milorad Pupovac]], president of [[Serb National Council]], said he expects that the [[Croatian government]] or [[Constitutional Court of Croatia]] would annul this decision.{{cite web|url=http://www.glassrpske.com/novosti/region/Cirilica-pred-Ustavnim-sudom/lat/138525.html|title=Ćirilica pred Ustavnim sudom|work=Glas Srpske|accessdate=10 November 2013}} ==See also== *[[Minority languages of Croatia]] *[[Minority language]] *[[European Charter for Regional or Minority Languages]] *[[Croatian Constitutional law on national minorities rights]] *[[Law on Use of Languages and Scripts of National Minorities]] *[[Anti-Serb sentiment]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Serbian minority institutions and organizations in Croatia}} {{DEFAULTSORT:2013 anti-bilingualism protests in Croatia}} [[Category:Vukovar]] [[Category:Protests in Croatia]] [[Category:2013 protests]] [[Category:2013 in Croatia]] [[Category:Right-wing populism in Europe]] [[Category:Human rights in Croatia]] [[Category:Serbs of Croatia]] [[Category:Anti-Serbian sentiment]] [[Category:Croatian nationalism]] [[Category:Linguistic controversies]]

In [[psychoanalysis]], '''anticathexis''', or countercathexis, is the energy used by the [[Id, ego and super-ego|ego]] to bind the primitive impulses of the [[Ego, superego, and id|Id]].<ref>Otto Fenichel, ''The Psychoanalytic Theory of Neurosis'' (London 1946) p. 42</ref> Sometimes the ego follows the instructions of the [[superego]] in doing so; sometimes however it develops a double-countercathexis, so as to block feelings of guilt and anxiety deriving from the superego, as well as id impulses.<ref>Fenichel, p. 132 and p. 479</ref>
==Repression and isolation==
[[Freud]] saw the establishment of a permanent anticathexis as a prerequisite for successful [[psychological repression]].<ref>[http://www.enotes.com/anticathexis-reference/anticathexis Anticathexis]</ref> He also saw countercathexis as playing a central role in [[Isolation (psychology)|isolation]].<ref>Fenichel, p. 155</ref>
In a late work, Freud further distinguished between the external anticathexis of repression and what he called “internal anticathexis" (i.e. alteration of the ego through [[reaction formation]]).<ref>Sigmund Freud, ''On Psychopathology'' (PFL 10) p. 318</ref>
==Figure-ground== Anticathexis has also been linked to the phenomenon of [[Figure-ground (perception)|figure-ground]], in that it may entail the suppression of the margin or ground of a perceptual field.<ref>R. Boothby, ''Freud as Philosopher'' (2001) p. 77</ref>
==See also== {{Columns-list|colwidth=22em| *[[Acathexis]] *[[Body cathexis]] *[[Cathexis]] *[[Decathexis]] *[[Psychological resistance]] }}
==References==
{{Reflist|2|}}
==Further reading== * [[J. Laplanche]]/J.-B. Pontalis, ''The Language of Psychoanalysis'' (2012)

{{infobox person/Wikidata | fetchwikidata=ALL | onlysourced=yes |birth_place = [[Time, Norway]] }} [[Image:Knudaheio.jpg|thumb|250px|right|Sculpture in stone of Arne Garborg, located at his home in Knudaheio]] '''Arne Garborg''', born Aadne Eivindsson Garborg (25 January 1851, [[Time, Norway|Time]] – 14 January 1924) was a [[Norway|Norwegian]] writer.
Garborg championed the use of [[Landsmål]] (now known as [[Nynorsk]], or New Norwegian), as a literary language; he translated the [[Odyssey]] into it. He founded the weekly ''Fedraheim'' in 1877, in which he urged reforms in many spheres including political, social, religious, agrarian, and linguistic. He was married to [[Hulda Garborg]].
He was nominated for the [[Nobel Prize in Literature]] six times.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nobelprize.org/nomination/archive/show_people.php?id=3323 |title=Nomination Database|website=www.nobelprize.org|access-date=2017-04-19}}</ref>
==Life and career== Garborg grew up on a farm named Garborg, near [[Undheim]], in [[Time, Norway|Time]] municipality at [[Jæren]] in [[Rogaland]] county. He grew up together with eight siblings. Although he was to become known as an author, it was as a newspaperman that he got his start. In 1872 he established the newspaper [[Tvedestrandsposten]], and in 1877 the [[Fedraheimen]], which he served as managing editor until 1892.<ref>His friend [[Ivar Mortensson-Egnund]] edited the paper “Fedraheimen” from 1883 until 1889.</ref> In the 1880s he was also a journalist for the [[Dagbladet]]. In 1894 he laid the ground, together with [[Rasmus Steinsvik]], for the paper ''Den 17de Mai'';<ref name="independenceday">Norway's independence day.</ref> which changed its name to [[Norsk Tidend]] in 1935.
His novels are profound and gripping while his essays are clear and insightful. He was never inclined to steer clear of controversy. His work tackled the issues of the day, including the relevance of religion in modern times, the conflicts between national and European identity, and the ability of the common people to actually participate in political processes and decisions.
In 2012 the [[Garborg Centre]] opened at [[Bryne]], Time. It is dedicated to the literature and philosophy of Arne and his wife, Hulda. Several of their homes are now turned into museums, like [[Garborgheimen]], [[Labråten]], [[Kolbotn]] and [[Knudaheio]].
<!-- Garborg viklet seg en tid inn i [[sedelighetsdebatten]], blant annet gjennom sine mange skriverier i [[Dagbladet]], og hans roman ''Mannfolk'' (1886) som ble beslaglagt av myndighetene og gjorde at Garborg mistet sin jobb i [[Riksrevisjonen]]. Garborg var særs kritisk til de radikale beskrivelser i [[Henrik Ibsen]]s Gjengangere. I [[målsaken]] var Garborg i opposisjon til [[Bjørnstjerne Bjørnson]], og mistet antakeligvis muligheten for å bestige redaktørposten i avisa. --> ===Bibliography=== [[Image:House at Jæren in Norway Garborgheimen.JPG|thumb|Garborg's birth home at Jæren is a museum today.]] [[Image:Eilif Peterssen-Arne Garborg.jpg|thumb|A painting of Arne Garborg by [[Eilif Peterssen]], from 1894]] * ''Ein Fritenkjar'' (1878) * ''Bondestudentar'' (1883) * ''Forteljingar og Sogar'' (1884) * ''[[Mannfolk]]'' (1886) * ''Uforsonlige'' (1888) * ''Hjaa ho Mor'' (1890) * ''Kolbotnbrev'' (1890) (Letters) * ''Trætte Mænd'' (1891) (published in English as ''[[Tired Men]]'' or ''[[Weary Men]]'') * ''Fred'' (1892) (published in English as ''[[Peace (Arne Garborg novel)|Peace]]'') * ''Jonas Lie. En Udviklingshistorie'' (1893) * ''[[Haugtussa]]'' (1895) (Poetry) * ''Læraren'' (1896) * ''Den burtkomme Faderen'' (1899) (published in English as ''The Lost Father'') * ''I Helheim'' (1901) * ''Knudahei-brev'' (1904) (Letters) * ''Jesus Messias'' (1906) * ''Heimkomin Son'' (1906) * ''Dagbok 1905–1923'' (1925–1927) (Diary) * ''Tankar og utsyn'' (1950) (Essays)
===Quotations=== "It is said that with money you can have everything, but you cannot. You can buy food, but not appetite; medicine but not health; knowledge but not wisdom; glitter, but not beauty; fun, but not joy; acquaintances, but not friends; servants, but not faithfulness; leisure, but not peace. You can have the husk of everything for money, but not the kernel."<ref name="clunypaper">Editorial. ''The Weekender Newspaper.'' Cluny, Alberta, Canada, March 4, 2005.</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}} *''The Literary Masters of Norway, with samples of their works'', introduced by Carl Henrik Grøndahl and Nina Tjomsland; Tanum-Norli, Oslo 1978
==External links== * [http://www.encyclopedia.com/html/G/Garborg.asp Arne Garborg, Columbia Encyclopedia] *[http://www.nb.no/nbsok/search?action=search&lang=en&mediatype=bøker&format=Digitalt%20tilgjengelig&searchString=creator:%22garborg,arne%22 Digitized books and manuscripts by Garborg] in the [[National Library of Norway]] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20060403100858/http://biphome.spray.se/torstein21/haugtussa.html Haugtussa<!-- bot-generated title -->] at biphome.spray.se is a link to the text of Garborg's cycle of poems "Haugtussa", which celebrates the landscape of [[Jæren]], where he grew up, and where he also built his study house "Knudaheio". *{{no icon}} [http://www.dokpro.uio.no/litteratur/garborg/ link to all his works, at UiO.no] * {{Gutenberg author |id=Garborg,+Arne | name=Arne Garborg}} * {{Internet Archive author |sname=Arne Garborg}} *[http://garborg.no/ Garborg Center]

{{Infobox language family |name=Berber |altname='''Tamaziɣt''' / '''Tamazight''' / '''ⵜⴰⵎⴰⵣⵉⵖⵜ''' / '''ⵝⴰⵎⴰⵣⵉⵗⵝ''' / '''ⵜⴰⵎⴰⵣⵉⵗⵜ''' |ethnicity=[[Berbers]] (''Imaziɣen'') |region=[[North Africa]], mainly [[Morocco]], [[Tunisia]], [[Algeria]], [[Libya]], northern [[Mali]] and northern [[Niger]]; smaller Berber-speaking populations in [[Burkina Faso]], [[Egypt]], [[Mauritania]] and the Spanish city of [[Melilla]], [[Morocco]]

Berber-speaking Moroccan and Algerian immigrants of about 2 million in: France, Netherlands, Belgium, Spain, Germany, Italy, Canada and the United States |familycolor=Afro-asiatic |protoname=[[Proto-Berber language|Proto-Berber]] |child1=[[Northern Berber languages|Northern]] |child2=[[Western Berber languages|Western]] |child3=[[Tuareg languages|Tuareg]] |child4=[[Eastern Berber languages|Eastern]] |child5=''[[Numidian language|East Numidian]]'' † |child6=''[[Guanche language|Guanche]]'' † |iso2=ber |iso5=ber |glotto=berb1260 |glottorefname=Berber |map=Map_of_Berber_Languages_2018.png |mapcaption=Berber-speaking populations are dominant in the coloured areas of modern-day North Africa. The other areas of North Africa contain minority Berber-speaking populations.
{{col-begin}}{{col-break}} '''Northern Berber''' ''Kabyle'' {{legend|#BA68C8| [[Kabyle language|Kabyle]] (Taqbaylit)}} ''Atlas'' {{legend|#E53935|[[Central Atlas Tamazight]] (Tamaziɣt)}} {{legend|#F06292|[[Shilha language|Shilha]] (Tacelḥit) }} {{legend|#AD1457|[[Sanhaja de Srair language|Senhaja de Srair]] & [[Ghomara language|Ghomara]]}} ''Zenati'' {{legend|#F57F17|[[Riffian language|Riffian]] (Tmaziɣt)}} {{legend|#FBC02D|[[Ait Seghrouchen Berber|Ayt Seghrouchen]] & [[Eastern Middle Atlas Berber|Ayt Warayn]]}} {{legend|#E65100|[[Shenwa language|Shenwa]]}} {{legend|#FF5722|[[Shawiya language|Shawiya]]}} {{legend|#FFFF00|Other Zenati ([[Mzab–Wargla languages|Mzab-Wargla]], [[East Zenati languages|East Zenati]])}} {{col-break}} '''Western Berber''' {{legend|#546E7A|[[Zenaga language|Zenaga]] (Tuḍḍungiyya)}} '''Eastern Berber''' {{legend|#00E676|[[Eastern Berber languages|Eastern Berber]] (Siwi, Nafusi, Sokna, Ghadamès, Awjila)}} '''Tuareg''' {{legend|#5C6BC0|[[Tuareg languages|Tuareg]] (Tamasheq)}} {{col-end}} }} {{Contains Tifinagh text}} The '''Berber languages''', also known as '''Berber''' or the '''Amazigh languages'''{{cite web|author=H. Ekkehard Wolff |url=http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/61496/Amazigh-languages |title=Amazigh languages |publisher=Britannica.com |date=2013-08-26 |accessdate=2015-07-14}} (Berber name: {{lang|ber-Latn|Tamaziɣt}}, {{lang|ber-Latn|Tamazight}}; [[Neo-Tifinagh]]: ⵜⴰⵎⴰⵣⵉⵖⵜ, [[Tuareg]] [[Tifinagh]]: ⵜⴰⵎⴰⵣⵉⵗⵜ, ⵝⴰⵎⴰⵣⵉⵗⵝ, {{IPA-tam|tæmæˈzɪɣt|pron}}, {{IPA-tam|θæmæˈzɪɣθ|}}), are a branch of the [[Afroasiatic language family]]. They comprise a group of closely related dialects spoken by the [[Berbers]], who are indigenous to [[North Africa]].Hayward, Richard J., chapter ''Afroasiatic'' in Heine, Bernd & Nurse, Derek, editors, ''African Languages: An Introduction'' Cambridge 2000. {{ISBN|0-521-66629-5}}. The languages were traditionally written with the ancient Libyco-Berber script, which now exists in the form of [[Tifinagh]].{{cite journal|last1=Briggs|first1=L. Cabot|title=A Review of the Physical Anthropology of the Sahara and Its Prehistoric Implications|journal=Man|volume=56|pages=20–23|date=February 1957}} Berber is spoken by large populations of [[Morocco]], [[Algeria]] and [[Libya]], by smaller populations of [[Tunisia]], northern [[Mali]], western and northern [[Niger]], northern [[Burkina Faso]] and [[Mauritania]] and in the [[Siwa Oasis]] of [[Egypt]]. Large Berber-speaking migrant communities, today numbering about 4 million, have been living in Western Europe, spanning over three generations, since the 1950s. The number of Berber people is much higher than the number of Berber speakers. The bulk of the populations of the [[Maghreb]] countries are considered to have Berber ancestors.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/3509799.stm|title=BBC NEWS. Q&A: The Berbers|date=2004-03-12|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=2013-04-30}} Around 90% of the Berber-speaking population speak one of seven major varieties of Berber, each with at least 2 million speakers. They are, in order of number of speakers: [[Shilha language|Shilha]] (''Tacelḥit/Tasussit''), [[Kabyle language|Kabyle]] (''Taqbaylit''), [[Central Atlas Tamazight]] (''Tamaziɣt''), [[Riffian language|Riffian]] (internal:''Tmaziɣt, external:Tarifit''), [[Shawiya language|Shawiya]] (''Tacawit'') and [[Tuareg languages|Tuareg]] (''Tamaceq/Tamajaq/Tamahaq''). The extinct [[Guanche language]] spoken on the [[Canary Islands]] by the [[Guanches]] as well as the languages of the ancient [[C-Group culture]] in present-day southern Egypt and northern [[Sudan]] are believed to have belonged to the Berber branch of the Afroasiatic family. The Berber languages and dialects have had a written tradition, on and off, for about 2,500 years, although the tradition has been frequently disrupted by cultural shifts and invasions. They were first written in the Libyco-Berber [[abjad]], which is still used today by the [[Tuareg people|Tuareg]] in the form of Tifinagh. The oldest dated inscription is from 3rd century BCE. Later, between about 1000 CE and 1500 CE, they were written in the [[Arabic script]], and since the 20th century they have been written in the [[Berber Latin alphabet]], especially among the [[Kabyle people|Kabyle]] and [[Riffian people|Riffian]] communities of Morocco and Algeria. The Berber Latin alphabet was also used by most European and Berber linguists during the 19th and 20th centuries.{{cite web|url=http://www.centrederechercheberbere.fr/la-langue-berbere.html|title=Centre de Recherche Berbère - La Langue Berbère|website=www.centrederechercheberbere.fr}} A modernised form of the Tifinagh alphabet, called [[Neo-Tifinagh]], was adopted in Morocco in 2003 for writing Berber, but many Moroccan Berber publications still use the Berber Latin alphabet. Algerians mostly use the Berber Latin alphabet in Berber-language education at public schools, while Tifinagh is mostly used for artistic symbolism. Mali and Niger recognise a Tuareg Berber Latin alphabet customised to the Tuareg phonological system. However, traditional Tifinagh is still used in those countries. There is a cultural and political movement among speakers of the closely related varieties of Northern Berber to promote and unify them under a written [[standard language]] called ''Tamaziɣt'' (or ''Tamazight''). The name ''Tamaziɣt'' is the current native name of the Berber language in the Moroccan [[Middle Atlas]] and [[Rif]] regions and the Libyan [[Zuwarah]] region. In other Berber-speaking areas, this name was lost. There is historical evidence from medieval Berber manuscripts that all indigenous North Africans from Libya to Morocco have at some point called their language ''Tamaziɣt''.{{cite journal|url=https://www.academia.edu/1268712/Some_grammatical_features_of_Ancient_Eastern_Berber_the_language_of_the_Mudawwana_|title=Some grammatical features of Ancient Eastern Berber (the language of the Mudawwana)|first=Vermondo|last=Brugnatelli|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.freemorocco.com/tamkardit-library/Grammatical_features_of_Eastern_Berber.pdf |format=PDF|title=Some grammatical features of ancient Eastern Berber |first= Vermondo |last=Brugnatelli|year= 2011|website=www.freemorocco.com}}{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books/about/Muhammad_Awzal_and_the_Berber_Literary_T.html?id=tsn7jwEACAAJ&redir_esc=y|title=Muhammad Awzal and the Berber Literary Tradition of the Sous|first=Nico Van den|last=Boogert|date=22 August 1995|publisher=|via=Google Books}} The name ''Tamaziɣt'' is currently being used increasingly by educated Berbers to refer to the written Berber language, and even to Berber as a whole, including Tuareg. In 2001, Berber became a constitutional [[national language]] of Algeria, and in 2011 Berber became a constitutionally [[official language]] of Morocco. In 2016, Berber became a constitutionally official language of Algeria alongside [[Arabic]].{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-35515769|title=Algeria reinstates term limit and recognises Berber language|publisher=BBC News}} ==Terminology== [[File:Tamazightchelha.ogg|thumb|right|180x180px|Speech sample in [[Shilha language|Shilha]] (Chelha).]] The term ''Berber'' has been used in Europe since at least the 17th century and is still used today. It was borrowed from [[Latin]] ''[[wikt:barbari#Noun 3|barbari]]''. The Latin word is also found in the Arabic designation for these populations, البربر (''al-Barbar''); see [[Names of the Berber people]]. Etymologically, the Berber root ''M-Z-Ɣ'' (''Mazigh'') (singular noun: ''Amazigh'', feminine: ''Tamazight'') means "free man", "noble man", or "defender". The feminine ''Tamazight'' traditionally referred specifically to the [[Riffian language|Riffian]] and [[Central Atlas Tamazight]] languages. Many Berber linguists prefer to consider the term ''Tamazight'' as a pure Berber word to be used only in Berber text while using the European word "Berber/''Berbero''/''Berbère''" in European texts to follow the traditions of European writings about the Berbers. European languages distinguish between the words "Berber" and "[[Barbarian#Berber and North African cultures|barbarian]]", while Arabic has the same word ''al-Barbari'' for both meanings. Some other Berber writers, especially in Morocco, prefer to refer to Berber with ''Amazigh'' when writing about it in French or English. Traditionally, the term ''Tamazight'' (in various forms: ''Thamazighth'', ''Tamasheq'', ''Tamajaq'', ''Tamahaq'') was used by many Berber groups to refer to the language they spoke, including the [[Central Atlas Tamazight|Middle Atlas]], the [[Riffian people|Riffians]], the [[Sened language|Sened]] in Tunisia and the [[Tuareg people|Tuareg]]. However, other terms were used by other groups; for instance, some Berber populations of Algeria called their language ''Taznatit'' ([[Zenata|Zenati]]) or ''Shelha'', while the [[Kabyle people|Kabyle]]s called theirs ''Taqbaylit'', and the inhabitants of the [[Siwa Oasis]] called their language ''Siwi''. In Tunisia, the local Amazigh language is usually referred to as ''Shelha'', a term which has been observed in Morocco as well.{{cite web|url=http://www.rosettaproject.org/live/search/showpages?ethnocode%3DZEN%26doctype%3Ddetail%26version%3D0%26scale%3Dsix |title=Archived copy |accessdate=June 28, 2004 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060927144458/http://www.rosettaproject.org/live/search/showpages?ethnocode=ZEN&doctype=detail&version=0&scale=six |archivedate=September 27, 2006 }} One group, the [[Linguasphere Observatory]], has attempted to introduce the [[neologism]] "Tamazic languages" to refer to the Berber languages.[http://www.linguasphere.info/lcontao/tl_files/pdf/master/OL-SITE%201999-2000%20MASTER%20ONE%20Sectors%201-Intro.pdf ''Afro-Asian Phylosector''] linguasphere.info. ==Origin== {{main article|Proto-Berber language}} Berber is a branch of the [[Afroasiatic languages|Afroasiatic]] language family.{{cite book|authors=Christopher Ehret; Bernd Heine, Derek Nurse (ed.)|title=African Languages: An Introduction|date=2000|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=0521666295|page=290|url=https://www.google.com/books?id=C7XhcYoFxaQC&pg=PA290|accessdate=27 December 2017}} Since modern Berber languages are relatively homogeneous, the date of the [[Proto-Berber language]] from which the modern group is derived was probably comparatively recent, comparable to the age of the [[Germanic languages|Germanic]] or [[Romance languages|Romance]] subfamilies. In contrast, the split of the group from the other Afroasiatic sub-phyla is much earlier, and is therefore sometimes associated with the local Mesolithic [[Capsian culture]].{{cite web|url=http://www.ddl.ish-lyon.cnrs.fr/equipes/index.asp?Action=Edit&Langue=EN&Equipe=3%20%20&Page=Action&ActionNum=26 |title=DDL : Evolution - Themes and actions |publisher=Ddl.ish-lyon.cnrs.fr |date= |accessdate=2015-07-14}} A number of extinct populations are believed to have spoken Afroasiatic languages of the Berber branch. According to Peter Behrens (1981) and Marianne Bechaus-Gerst (2000), linguistic evidence suggests that the peoples of the [[C-Group culture]] in present-day southern [[Egypt]] and northern [[Sudan]] spoke Berber languages.{{cite book|last1=Marianne Bechaus-Gerst|first1=Roger Blench, Kevin MacDonald (ed.)|title=The Origins and Development of African Livestock: Archaeology, Genetics, Linguistics and Ethnography – "Linguistic evidence for the prehistory of livestock in Sudan" (2000)|date=2014|publisher=Routledge|isbn=1135434166|pages=453–457|url=https://www.google.com/books?id=-t5QAwAAQBAJ|accessdate=16 April 2015}}{{cite book|last1=Behrens|first1=Peter|title=Libya Antiqua: Report and Papers of the Symposium Organized by Unesco in Paris, 16 to 18 January 1984 – "Language and migrations of the early Saharan cattle herders: the formation of the Berber branch"|date=1986|publisher=Unesco|isbn=9231023764|page=30|url=https://www.google.com/books?id=p_hwAAAAMAAJ|accessdate=16 April 2015}} The [[Nilo-Saharan languages|Nilo-Saharan]] [[Nobiin language]] today contains a number of key pastoralism related [[loanword]]s that are of Berber origin, including the terms for sheep and water/[[Nile]]. This in turn suggests that the C-Group population — which, along with the [[Kerma Culture|Kerma culture]], inhabited the Nile valley immediately before the arrival of the first [[Nubian languages|Nubian]] speakers — spoke Afro-Asiatic languages. [[Roger Blench]] (2018)Blench, Roger. 2018. [https://www.academia.edu/36664366/Reconciling_archaeological_and_linguistic_evidence_for_Berber_prehistory Reconciling archaeological and linguistic evidence for Berber prehistory]. suggests that Proto-Berber speakers had spread from the Nile River valley to North Africa 4,000-5,000 years ago due to the spread of pastoralism, and experienced intense language leveling about 2,000 years ago as the [[Roman Empire]] was expanding in North Africa. Hence, although Berber had split off from Afroasiatic several thousand years ago, Proto-Berber itself can only be reconstructed to a period as late as 200 A.D. Blench (2018) notes that Berber is considerably different from other Afroasiatic branches, but modern-day Berber languages display low internal diversity. The presence of [[Punic language|Punic]] borrowings in Proto-Berber points to the diversification of modern Berber language varieties subsequent to the fall of [[Ancient Carthage|Carthage]] in 146 B.C.; only [[Zenaga language|Zenaga]] lacks Punic loanwords. Additionally, [[Latin language|Latin]] loanwords in Proto-Berber point to the breakup of Proto-Berber between 0-200 A.D. During this time period, Roman innovations including the ox-plough, camel, and orchard management were adopted by Berber communities along the ''[[limes]]'', or borders of the Roman Empire. This resulted in a new trading culture involving the use of a [[lingua franca]] which became Proto-Berber. ==Orthography== {{Main article|Berber orthography}} [[File:Prehistory-draa16.jpg|thumb|Ancient [[Tifinagh|Libyco-Berber]] inscriptions in [[Zagora, Morocco|Zagora]], Morocco]] Various orthographies have been used to transcribe the Berber languages. In antiquity, the Libyco-Berber script ([[Tifinagh]]) was utilised to write Berber. Early uses of the script have been found on [[rock art]] and in various [[sepulchre]]s. Among these are the 1,500 year old [[Tin Hinan Tomb|monumental tomb]] of the Tuareg matriarch [[Tin Hinan]], where vestiges of a Tifinagh inscription have been found on one of its walls.{{cite journal|last1=Briggs|first1=L. Cabot|title=A Review of the Physical Anthropology of the Sahara and Its Prehistoric Implications|journal=Man|date=February 1957|volume=56|pages=20–23|jstor=2793877}} Following the spread of [[Islam]], some Berber scholars also utilised the [[Arabic script]].{{Harvcoltxt|Ben-Layashi|2007|p=166}} There are now three writing systems in use for Berber languages: Tifinagh, the Arabic script, and the [[Berber Latin alphabet]].{{cite journal| last = Larbi| first = Hsen| title = Which Script for Tamazight, Whose Choice is it ?| journal = Amazigh Voice (Taghect Tamazight)| volume = 12| issue = 2| year = 2003| publisher = Amazigh Cultural Association in America (ACAA)| location = New Jersey| url = http://www.tamazgha.fr/Which-Script-for-Tamazight-Whose-Choice-is-it,359.html| accessdate = December 17, 2009 }} ==Phonology== ===Vowels=== {| class="wikitable" ! !
